overview: This subject will teach you how to manage a patient with major trauma, septic shock, and severe anaemia; to perform and interpret an AFAST scan and give a blood transfusion. Both the pathophysiology and clinical aspects of the following conditions are covered: trauma, burns, hyperthermia, toxicities, coagulopathies, IMHA, IMT, anaphylaxis, diabetic ketoacidosis, Addisonian crisis, hyperosmolar hyperglycaemic syndrome, SIRS/sepsis and DIC. This subject will build on knowledge that was acquired as an undergraduate leading to a deeper understanding and improved clinical confidence of these conditions.
ilo: Identify sound management decisions based on pathophysiological principles.
Interpret clinical and diagnostic findings in order to identify sound management plans.
Recall the mechanism of action of medications.
generic_skills: increased confidence in tackling unfamiliar problems
the capacity to manage competing demands on time

Prerequisites.content: This subject is not available for students admitted in any other courses.

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Self-assessment by multiple choice questions, 10 MCQ for each of 10 tutorials, takes 20 minutes - following each tutorial and one prior to subject completion
50 MCQ open book examination, during exam week
assessment.hurdle: To pass this examination, a minimum mark of 70% is required.

assessment.brief: Interpretation of 25 case studies assessed by structured questions pertaining to each case - 5 MCQ per case
